newsitem.title: USA: EPA sets tolerance for pesticide bromoxynil.
newsitem.headline: EPA sets tolerance for pesticide bromoxynil.

text.p: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency on Friday set a one-year allowable residue level for the weed-control pesticide bromoxynil on cotton commodities, and on meat, milk, and poultry products.
EPA also said it would allow the pesticide to be used on only 400,000 acres, or about 3.0 percent of cotton acreage.
Bromoxynil, made by Rhone-Poulenc, is used on cottonseeds that are genetically engineered to resist the pesticide, which is used on growing cotton plants to kill broadleaf weeds.

Under new health-based standards for food quality, the EPA determined that while bromoxynil caused cancer and birth defects in lab animals, "there is a reasonable certainty of no harm to humans, wildlife and fish given the exposure levels expected."
The agency set tolerances for the pesticide on meat, milk and poultry products because cotton commodities are used on some animal feeds.
